priority is no longer used, so that is blank

description.compact: Parses a template and returns any translatable entities

comment.value: Run the parser and throw away the result

description.compact: Stores the user-supplied closed block extension rules in the form: array( 'name' => function (&$res) {} ) See SSTemplateParser::ClosedBlock_Handle_Loop for an example of what the callable should look like

Stores the user-supplied open block extension rules in the form: array( 'name' => function (&$res) {} ) See SSTemplateParser::OpenBlock_Handle_Base_tag for an example of what the callable should look like
Allow the injection of new closed & open block callables
Override the function that constructs the result arrays to also prepare a 'php' item in the array
Set the closed blocks that the template parser should use

docblock.description: This method will delete any existing closed blocks, please use addClosedBlock if you don't want to overwrite

description.compact: Set the open blocks that the template parser should use

docblock.description: This method will delete any existing open blocks, please use addOpenBlock if you don't want to overwrite

description.compact: Add a closed block callable to allow <% name %><% end_name %> syntax

param.description: The name of the token to be used in the syntax <% name %><% end_name %>
The function that modifies the generation of template code

description.compact: Add a closed block callable to allow <% name %> syntax

param.description: The name of the token to be used in the syntax <% name %>
The function that modifies the generation of template code

description.compact: Ensures that the arguments to addOpenBlock and addClosedBlock are valid
Values are bare words in templates, but strings in PHP. We rely on PHP's type conversion to back-convert strings to numbers when needed.

The basic generated PHP of LookupStep and LastLookupStep is the same, except that LookupStep calls 'obj' to get the next ViewableData in the sequence, and LastLookupStep calls different methods (XML_val, hasValue, obj) depending on the context the lookup is used in.

comment.value: remove last comma in the array

description.compact: If we get a bare value, we don't know enough to determine exactly what php would be the translation, because we don't know if the position of use indicates a lookup or a string argument.

docblock.description:
Instead, we record 'ArgumentMode' as a member of this matches results node, which can be: - lookup if this argument was unambiguously a lookup (marked as such) - string is this argument was unambiguously a string (marked as such, or impossible to parse as lookup) - default if this argument needs to be handled as per 2.4
In the case of 'default', there is no php member of the results node, but instead 'lookup_php', which should be used by the parent if the context indicates a lookup, and 'string_php' which should be used if the context indicates a string

comment.value: Get the block counter
Build the key for this block from the global key (evaluated in a closure within the template),
the passed cache key, the block index, and the sha hash of the template.
Embed the code necessary to evaluate the globalKey directly into the template,
so that SSTemplateParser only needs to be called during template regeneration.
Warning: If the global key is changed, it's necessary to flush the template cache.
block index
Get any condition
Add include filename comments on dev sites

description.compact: As mentioned in the parser comment, block handling is kept fairly generic for extensibility. The match rule builds up two important elements in the match result array: 'ArgumentCount' - how many arguments were passed in the opening tag 'Arguments' an array of the Argument match rule result arrays

docblock.description:
Once a block has successfully been matched against, it will then look for the actual handler, which should be on this class (either defined or extended on) as ClosedBlock_Handler_Name(&$res), where Name is the tag name, first letter captialized (i.e Control, Loop, With, etc).
This function will be called with the match rule result array as it's first argument. It should return the php result of this block as it's return value, or throw an error if incorrect arguments were passed.

description.compact: This is an example of a block handler function. This one handles the loop tag.

comment.value: loop without arguments loops on the current scope

description.compact: Compiles some passed template source code into the php code that will execute as per the template source.

param.description: The name of the template, normally the filename the template source was loaded from
True is debugging comments should be included in the output
True if this is a top template, false if it's just a template

return.description: The php that, when executed (via include or exec) will behave as per the template source

comment.value: Include top level debugging comments if desired
If this template contains a doctype, put it right after it,
if not, put it after the <html> tag to avoid IE glitches

param.description: A file path that contains template source code

return.description: - The php that, when executed (via include or exec) will behave as per the template source
